xml.title: Summary
xml.body:
Validating techniques for biogeochemistry products can take spatial and temporal factors into consideration by making use of a neighbouring method technique. The technique comprises that a window of variability is applied to the model output results. The variability window allows comparing satellite pixel values with model pixel values that are in the neighbourhood of the pixel of concern. The shape of the window can be rigid or flexible according to what the information is wanted from the validation. Three shapes for the variability window were tested in time and space.

The neighbouring method as applied in this work, concentrates on validating biogeochemistry models with satellite data. The technique is suitable for validating a biogeochemistry model with point. Satellite validation has as a consequence only surface chlorophyll model output is regarded. Though the principles for the temporal and spatial dimension are the same, time is usually not tested in applications of neighbouring method techniques. Hence, we demonstrate the use of a window variability in time.

Below the different variability windows that were tested are described (more possibilities exits). The window method is visualised by representing the databases matrices as cubes, as they are 3D (time, longitude and latitude). The satellite cube is blue, the model output cube light green and the output used after applying the window is dark green. See the window methods used here.

Three types of skill metrics are used to compare satellite and model results: details of the classic continuous skill metrics, categorical metrics and the p90 value maps can be found here.

To make sure the evaluation of the neighbouring method is not biased by model or area specific anomalies, three different domains were tested. The satellite products of MyOcean were used. The details of the domains used are found here.
